review.title: Consensus of rankings
review.abstract: Rankings are widely used in many information systems. In information retrieval, a ranking is a list of ordered documents, in which a document with lower position has higher ranking score than the documents behind it. This paper studies the consensus measure for a given set of rankings, in order to understand the degree to which the rankings agree and the extent to which the rankings are related. The proposed multi-facet approach, without the need for pairwise comparison between rankings, allows to measure the consensus in a set of rankings, with respect to the length of common patterns, the number of common patterns for a given length, and the number of all common patterns. The experiments show that the proposed approach can be used to compare the search engines in terms of closeness of the returned results when semantically related key words are sent to them.

When retrieving information, a ranking is a list of ordered documents in which a document with a lower ranking has a higher ranking score than the documents on which it is based. This paper examines the consensus yardsticks for a given set of rankings to understand the extent to which the rankings match and the extent to which the rankings are related to each other. The proposed approach, without the need for a pair-by-pair comparison between rankings, allows to measure the consensus in a set of rankings, in terms of the length of common patterns, the number of common patterns for a given length, and the number of common patterns. The experiments show that the proposed approach can be used to compare search engines with respect to the proximity of returned results when semantically related keywords are sent to them.

sections.heading: 1 Introduction
sections.text: Rankings are widely used in information gathering, recommendation and decision-making systems [1, 4, 5]. A ranking is a list of sorted terms in which an item with a lower ranking is rated. Retrieving information is a typical example of the use of rankings in which a ranking result is returned as a result of ordered documents after a query. Automatic suggestions, an important part of search engines nowadays, produce a ranking of search terms according to one or two keystrokes to provide a better search experience.The problem with consensus ranking measurement is the quantification of the degree to which rankings match according to certain common patterns. Formally, a set of R = {r1, · · rN} of N rankings consists of quantifying and evaluating the commonalities.

sections.heading: 4 Experiments
sections.text: This section presents the results of applying the proposed algorithms to compare search results with Google and Bing. The keywords used are "Bond Movies," "Bond Movies," "007 Movies," "James Bond Movies" and "James Bond Movies," as these keywords refer to an identical concept. We generate each ranking with the 25 most unique links from the search engines after each keyword has been sent. Table 1 shows 12 rankings from the two search engines, in which each search engine has 6 rankings corresponding to the 6 keywords. In the 12 rankings, we get a total of 98 unique links, of which Bing provides 59 unique links and Google 60 unique links. The aim of this experiment is to evaluate the search results based on the proposed measure of "kinship" or "proximity" with the specified conceptually related keywords. Table 2 shows the results from which we can find out that the six rankings consist of the Bing links, each having the least common (R = 8) while Google has the least common (R = 8).

sections.heading: 5 Conclusion
sections.text: This paper discusses the consensus benchmarks for a given set of rankings to understand the extent to which the rankings match and the extent to which the rankings are related to each other. We propose an approach to measuring consensus in a set of rankings, in terms of the length of common patterns, the number of common patterns for a given length, and the number of common patterns. We use Google and Bing search results with the given keywords in the experiment, which shows how the proposed approach can be used to evaluate search quality in terms of proximity and relatedness when using conceptually related keywords.Future work includes how the common patterns can be extracted and how the proposed approach can be used for ranking.
